Wins enough votes in the Texas GOP senatorial primary to force a runoff.
Defeats Texas Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst in the runoff election for the Republican Senate nomination, by a vote of 57% to 43%.
Elected US senator from Texas by defeating Democrat Paul Sadler, 56% to 41%.
Named vice chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.
Sworn in as the 34th US senator from Texas.
Reads Dr. Seuss's "Green Eggs and Ham" as a bedtime story for his children during a 21-hour speech
Cruz announces his candidacy for president in a 30-second video message posted on Twitter shortly after midnight.
Later in the day he announces he is running for president during a speech at Liberty University in Lynchburg, Virginia.

Cruz formally names Carly Fiorina as his vice presidential running mate -- a last-ditch move to regain momentum after being mathematically eliminated from winning the GOP presidential nomination outright.
Cruz announces he is suspending his presidential bid after losing the Indiana primary.
Ending speculation about whether he would take a break from Congress to prep for another presidential run in 2020, Cruz announces that he will, in fact, campaign to keep his Senate seat in 2018.

Cruz endorses Donald Trump for the presidency, surprising many after a contentious primary filled with nasty personal attacks and Cruz's dramatic snub of Trump at the Republican National Convention, where he pointedly refused to endorse the nominee.
